content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)

The indefinite integral of cos(x) is sin(x). Substituting x=4 into this result gives sin(4) = 2. However, as this is a complex number, it cannot be represented as a single integer. Please provide more information about the context of your question, so that I can better assist you.

The indefinite integral of cos(x) is -sin(x). Substituting x=4 into this result gives sin(4) = -sin(4). However, as this is a complex number, it cannot be represented as a single integer. Please provide more information about the context of your question, so that I can better assist you.
